Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Investigating School District Resilience and the Impact of Hurricane Exposure on Student Outcomes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
North Carolina has experienced 11 major disasters due to hurricanes or tropical storms over the past 20 years. Moreover, one tropical cyclone has hit the state every two years since 1851. Although natural disasters are frequent, efforts to understand and support public schools' responses to such disasters are rare. This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project is an exploratory mixed methods study investigating the impact of vulnerability and resilience in the recovery of North Carolina schools affected by both Hurricanes Florence (2018) and Matthew (2016). Specifically, the study assesses whether schools that were impacted by both storms used organizational learning strategies to recover faster than schools that were impacted by either Hurricane Florence or Matthew alone. The project pursues three research questions: (1) What characteristics predict school district resilience? (2) How does prior disaster experience aid/hinder a resilient recovery? (3) Do students in resilient districts show less learning loss or rebound from learning loss more quickly?

This mixed methods project will involve interviews, focus groups and surveys with school and district personnel in a purposive sample of 15 districts across North Carolina that were heavily impacted by both storms and those that were affected by only one. These qualitative data will be used to derive markers of resilience that will then be used in quantitative analyses. Quantitative comparisons of state-wide data on student outcomes (e.g., achievement, attendance) will also be made across three kinds of districts: those that were affected by both storms, those that were affected by only one storm and those that were not affected at all. Quantitative data will be taken from an existing longitudinal database that includes individual student characteristics, attendance, suspensions and academic performance for all students in North Carolina. The purposive sampling of 15 districts in North Carolina allows for a novel comparison of impact, recovery and organizational learning across two disasters and over time. Disasters can create an opportunity for organizational change leading to greater resiliency in future crises; however, little extant research has focused on whether and how schools recover and remain resilient in the aftermath of natural disasters, such as hurricanes. This project can benefit schools in crisis by providing lessons learned and a roadmap for action to schools that are singularly and repeatedly impacted by natural disasters.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project aims to investigate the vulnerability and resiliency of schools affected by Hurricanes Florence and Matthew. Specifically, the research team used an exploratory mixed methods design and conducted interviews, administered surveys, and analyzed longitudinal student outcome data across North Carolina. The team applied the following three research questions as a foundation for the study, (1) What characteristics predict school district resilience? (2) How does prior disaster experience aid/hinder a resilient recovery? And, (3) Do students in resilient districts show less learning loss or rebound from learning loss quicker?

Current research looks at the role of organizational learning in promoting resilience for communities, but no existing research considers the role of school districts. The research team had a unique opportunity to collect data from school districts that were impacted by two consecutive hurricanes and compare them to sampled districts that were primarily affected by one hurricane. This prospect allowed the research team to gather information that explored, how, if at all, schools remain resilient after a hurricane and whether concurrent storms create an atmosphere for organizational growth within schools.

To answer these questions, the research team identified 15 districts - five districts impacted by both Hurricanes Florence and Matthew, five that were solely a by Hurricane Florence in 2018, and five that were only affected by Hurricane Matthew in 2016. The team conducted 53 interviews with school and district administrators. Additionally, the team administered an online survey to educators and collected responses from 4,259 school personnel.  Finally, the research team compiled student datasets from 2011-12 to 2018-19 academic years and employed a difference-in-difference approach to compare results from districts impacted by hurricanes to those that were not impacted.

Qualitative results revealed two key themes; (1) schools improved preparation, communication, and organization regardless of singular or multiple impacts from hurricanes, and (2) educators impacted by both storms were more likely to express feeling fatigued and stressed.

In the first theme, educators expressed developing organizational learning strategies regardless of how a hurricane affected them. Interview and survey participants whose districts were only affected by Florence observed that neighboring counties affected by Matthew provided valuable insights into preparation for an impending disaster. Similarly, districts affected by Matthew shared that applying the lessons learned in 2016 helped mitigate damage from Florence in 2018. Applying previous lessons learned were crucial for improving response in districts that experienced both hurricanes. This feeling was also reflected in the survey responses from educators. Over half of respondents said their district was more prepared for Hurricane Florence than Matthew; whereas less than 10 percent said they were less prepared.

While interviewees gave mostly positive feedback about the changes in districts’ crisis management during the hurricanes, principals noted one important continued theme: how schools are used as emergency shelters for the local community. School administration is required to oversee shelter operations at their schools—a task that needs more logistical clarity and guidance from district- and county-level leaders. For this reason, respondents suggested that future crisis planning at the county level involves school leaders who can provide insights about the challenges encountered with operating emergency shelters.

The second key theme that emerged from the qualitative analysis was that teachers and staff in areas hit by both hurricanes often experienced prolonged stress and fatigue—both from personal trauma and loss from the storm and from helping students navigate the emotional impacts of these disasters. An overwhelming majority of surveyed teachers were concerned about their mental health after the storm and expressed concerns about their colleagues’ mental health. Following a disaster, teachers often sacrificed personal time and well-being to help students and their communities. Some participants worried about the long-term emotional toll the crisis would have on teachers. In summary, thorough preparation and emotional support are critical in the mitigation of disasters.

Quantitative analysis of student outcome data revealed negative impacts of hurricane exposure on student test scores in elementary school reading and math; middle school reading, math, and science; and high school English and Biology.  The size of these effects were generally between 1.5 and 3 percent of a standard deviation.  In the years following Hurricane Matthew, the hurricane’s effect on test scores began to fade out.  Analysis of outcomes in the participating districts revealed similar results.  However, among participating districts, those that were impacted by both hurricanes saw smaller effects from Hurricane Florence than those districts only affected by Hurricane Florence.  If anything, suspension rates were reduced following exposure to hurricanes, and absences were increased following Hurricane Matthew but not Hurricane Florence.  These findings may reflect a greater willingness of school personnel to accommodate students after the hurricanes.
